Enrollment Policy for Math 104, 110, 113, 128A, and 185

During "Phase 1" of registration, seats in Math 104, 110, 113, 128A and 185 will be reserved for students in the following 3 groups...

--Declared Mathematics and Applied Math majors

--Undeclared students in the College of Letters & Science

--Incoming Math & Applied Math Fall 2018 transfer students

 

Students who are currently declared in another major but who plan to double-major with Math or Applied Math should plan to add their double-major within the next 4-5 weeks if they want Phase 1 priority for registering for Math 104, 110, 113, 128A or 185 in Fall 2018.   Instructions for declaring the major can be found here (and including booking an appointment with Math advisors Ana Renteria or Thomas Brown).

 

Graduate students, undergraduates from outside of Letters & Science, and declared Letters & Science students who aren't double or triple majoring with Mathematics or Applied Mathematics will need to add to the waiting list during Phase 1 or wait until Phase 2 to add these courses.  The department remains committed to doing our best to meet the demand for math courses from all majors.

Satisfy the Philosophy breadth with Phil 12A online this summer!

Instructor: Wasley Holliday

CCN: 15204

 

Logical reasoning is essential in most areas of human inquiry. The discipline of Logic treats logical reasoning itself as an object of study. Logic has been one of the main branches of philosophy since Aristotle; it revolutionized the foundations of mathematics in the 20th century; and it has been called “the calculus of computer science,” with applications in many areas. Logic has also played an important role in the investigation of language and the mind, as the basis for formal semantics in linguistics and automated reasoning in artificial intelligence. Today, Logic is an interdisciplinary subject with many applications.

PHILOS 12A is intended as a first course in logic for students with no previous exposure to the subject. The course treats symbolic logic. Students will learn to formalize reasoning in symbolic languages with precisely defined meanings and precisely defined rules of inference. Symbolic logic is by nature a mathematical subject, but the course does not presuppose any prior coursework in mathematics—only an openness to mathematical reasoning.

Students from philosophy, mathematics, computer science, and linguistics will find important connections between the symbolic logic covered in 12A and their other coursework.

Computer Vision Internship Opportunity @ SafelyYou

Our startup, SafelyYou is applying computer vision to support elderly living with dementia. Alzheimer's, a type of Dementia is the most costly disease in the US. 26% of Alzheimer's related hospitalization are caused by people "falling" down.  We recently published a paper shows 80% reduction in the number of falls in one nursing home and have signed pilot agreements or received requests to pilot from the largest senior living providers in the US, Canada, and Japan.

 

We have raised 1.5M+$ in funding and are looking to hire an exceptionally talented computer vision engineer to tackle a range of interesting problems ranging from domain adaption, low shot recognition and generalization to long-tail. The current opening is for an internship in Summer 2018, with the possibility of a full-time offer at the end of the internship. Our current engineering talent is from Berkeley, Stanford, CMU and Ecole Polytechnique. We have extensive support from UCSF and other well-known experts on the clinical side. You can find more about us at: https://www.safely-you.com/. We are based in Berkeley, CA.

 

If you are interested or have any questions about this internship opportunity, reach out to Pulkit (pulkitag@safely-you.com) or George (gnetscher@safely-you.com). The minimum eligibility requirements are: expertise in deep learning, in-depth experience in using either caffe (preferred), tensorflow or pytorch and programming experience in python.

Summer Design courses and programs at Jacobs Hall

The Jacobs Institute is offering four hands-on Design Innovation courses this summer. These for-credit courses provide entry points to core design skills that apply across disciplines — and they’re open to anyone. Whether you’re a Berkeley undergraduate hoping to get ahead or a visitor interested in picking up a valuable new skill, you're welcome here. All courses run June 4 to August 10.

 

DES INV 10: Discovering Design

This course, ideal for students who are looking for an introduction to the broad world of design, covers design careers, history, ethics, and more. You'll be learning design both from theoretical perspectives and from studio-based design projects.

 

DES INV 15: Design Methodology

In this class, you will explore the mindset, skillset and toolset associated with design. Over the course of the summer, you will learn and apply approaches to noticing and observing, framing and reframing, imagining and designing, and experimenting and testing.

 

DES INV 21: Visual Communication & Sketching

Good ideas alone are not the key to being a great designer or innovator — strong process and communication skills will make you stand out. This course will give participants practice and confidence in their ability to sketch by hand, communicate visually, and tell captivating stories.

 

DES INV 22: Prototyping & Fabrication

Explore a range of prototyping and fabrication techniques — including laser-cutting, 3D modeling and 3D printing, soldering, basic circuits, microcontrollers (Arduino), sensors and actuators, and interface mockups — as you create original projects.

Cybersecurity & Cyber-Physical Systems REU

See attachment.

Career Options: Technical Writing

Hosted by Society of Women Engineers

Technical writer/editors communicate and clarify complex scientific information for target audiences, from customers to CEOs. You can work on a wide range of projects, including website copy, magazine articles, user guides, scientific reports, and marketing materials—and everything in between.

 

Come to the third event of the Career Options in Engineering series to hear from representatives of Sandia National Laboratories. They will be talking about their work experiences and exciting career opportunities in technical writing for students with engineering backgrounds who are also passionate about communication and writing.

 

Speakers include Emmeline Chen (Technical Writer and Editor) and Sarah Sewell (Program Communications Specialist).

 

Dinner will be provided! We will be raffling off a Hydro Flask water bottle to participants who fill out our feedback form.

Turing Award Winner & Google VP Vint Cerf at the Berkeley Forum

 

Location: Anna Head Alumnae Hall

Time: 3/7/18 @ 6:00 PM

 

All tickets for UC Berkeley students, faculty, and staff are free.

 

Facebook link: https://www.facebook.com/events/360851951064917/

Eventbrite link: http://bforu.me/cerf-ml

 

THE UNFINISHED INTERNET - VINT CERF AT THE BERKELEY FORUM

The Internet has been evolving since 1973 and has been in operation since 1983. It has continued to evolve and now serves about half the Earth's population. We have learned a great deal since the advent of the World Wide Web and online social media and among the lessons are that the Internet can be abused in ways that produce social harm as well as social and economic good. Coping with this is an unsolved challenge. Further elaboration of the online world is already underway with the Internet of Things and the Interplanetary Internet. Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning is infusing the online world with new capabilities only dreamed of decades ago. In this talk, Vint Cerf will argue that the technical community has obligations to assure that these technologies are mostly constructive and that the hazards of their application are mitigated technically, legally, and socially.

 

Vinton (Vint) Cerf is a celebrated computer scientist, described as one of the "fathers of the Internet." He is most well known for creating the TCP/IP protocol suite with Robert Kahn. His awards and honors include the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the National Medal of Technology, the Turing Award (sometimes referred to as the "Nobel Prize of computer science"), the Marconi Prize, the Japan Prize, as well as election into the National Academy of Engineering, and the Royal Society as a foreign member (ForMemRS). Cerf was the founding president of the Internet Society. He was instrumental in the founding of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) and served as its chairman. Cerf also served as President of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM). He currently serves on the National Science Board. Cerf is a Vice President and Chief Internet Evangelist at Google.
